work.p: This manuscript likely contributed to the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself." Whitman mentions the "superb wonder of a blade of grass," as well as referencing the term "Koboo," which appeared in the poem in 1855. The idea of "[e]nter[ing] into the thoughts of the different theological faiths" (described in this manuscript) can also be connected to the stanza of "Song of Myself" that begins "I do not despise you priests..."

titleStmt.title: For example, whisper
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

notesStmt.note: This manuscript likely contributed to the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself." Whitman mentions the "superb wonder of a blade of grass," as well as referencing the term "Koboo," which appeared in the poem in 1855. The manuscript has not been found: in Notes and Fragments, Richard Maurice Bucke describes it as "torn and almost falling to pieces" (Grier 1:163). The date of the manuscript is almost certainly before 1855.

biblStruct.note: Grier derives his text from Notes & Fragments, ed. Richard Maurice Bucke (London, Ontario: A. Talbot & Co., printers, 1899), 168.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: For example, whisper
bibl.orgName: The location of this manuscript is unknown.

body.p: For example, whisper privately in your ear . . . the studies . . . be a rich investment if they . . . to bring the hat instantly off the . . . all his learning and bend himself to feel and fully enjoy . . . superb wonder of a blade of grass growing up green and crispy from the ground. Enter into the thoughts of the different theological faiths—effuse all that the believing Egyptian would—all that the Greek—all that the Hindoo, worshipping Brahma—the Koboo adoring his fetish stone or log—the Presbyterian—the Catholic with his crucifix and saints—the Turk with the Koran.
